First, when the user started, object 3 was on the machine. Then they took it off, and the machine's light was off. Then they started putting objects 0, 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 on the machine one by one, but the light stayed off each time. Only when they added object 3 back on the machine did the light turn on. 

Then, when they took object 0 off, the light remained on. But when they removed object 3, the light turned off again. When they put object 3 back alone, the light came on. 

This suggests that object 3 is definitely a blicket because its presence alone activates the machine. The other objects (0,1,2,4,5,6,7) were all on the machine together without object 3, but the light didn't turn on. Even when they added all those objects except 3, the machine didn't activate. Only when 3 was added did it work. 

Since object 7 was part of a group that didn't activate the machine without 3, and adding 7 alone (assuming in the final test where 3 is on the machine, taking others off except 3 kept it on), there's no evidence that 7 contributes. The machine only requires object 3 to be present. Therefore, object 7 is not a blicket.
